author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “My existence is a scandal”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “How pale the Princess is! Never have I seen her so pale. She is like the shadow of a white rose in a mirror of silver.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Art finds her own perfection within, and not outside of, herself.She is not to be judged by any external standard of resemblance.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I'm too old to know everything”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “In all matters of opinion, our adversaries are insane.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “If we're always guided by other people's thoughts, what's the point in having our own?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Circumstances should never alter principles!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I will not bare my soul to their shallow prying eyes. My heart shall never be put under their microscope.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The artist is the creator of beautiful things. To reveal art and conceal the artist is art's aim.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is because Humanity has never known where it was going that it has been able to find its way.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “When critics disagree the artist is in accord with himself.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Bad artists always admire each others work.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Spontaneity is a meticulously prepared art”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “A man who takes himself too seriously will find that no one else takes him seriously.”
author: Oscar Wilde

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I wish you would tell me your secret. To get back my youth I would do anything in the world, except take exercise, get up early, or be respectable.”
author: Oscar Wilde

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “My experience is that as soon as people are old enough to know better, they don't know anything at all.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Men always want to be a woman's first love - women like to be a man's last romance.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The happiness of a married man depends on the people he has not married.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “LADY BRACKNELLTo speak frankly, I am not in favour of long engagements. They give people the opportunity of finding out each other's character before marriage, which I think is never advisable.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is a great mistake for men to give up paying compliments, for when they give up saying what is charming, they give up thinking what is charming.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You can hardly imagine that I and Lord Bracknell would dream of allowing our only daughter - a girl brought up with the utmost care - to marry into a cloak-room, and form an alliance with a parcel?”

quote: “Good taste is the excuse I've always given for leading such a bad life”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One of the great secrets of life. Most people die of a sort of creeping common sense and discover too late that the only things one never regrets are one's mistakes.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “He lives the poetry that he cannot write. The others write the poetry that they dare not realize”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Travel improves the mind wonderfully, and does away with all one’s prejudices.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I have always been of opinion that hard work is simply the refuge of people who have nothing whatever to do.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Life is terrible. It rules us, we do not rule it.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I quite agree with Dr. Nordau's assertion that all men of genius are insane, but Dr. Nordau forgets that all sane people are idiots.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The only way to atone for being occasionally a little over-dressed is by being always absolutely over-educated.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You can't possibly ask me to go without having some dinner. It's absurd. I never go without my dinner. No one ever does, except vegetarians and people like that.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There was purification in punishment. Not 'Forgive us our sins,' but 'Smite us for our iniquities' should be the prayer of a man to a most just God.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The bond of all companionship, whether in marriage or in friendship, is conversation”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “this woman is a genius in the day time and a beauty at night”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “If people are dishonest once, they will be dishonest a second time. And honest people should keep away from them. (Lady Chiltern)”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Cecily. This is no time for wearing the shallow mask of manners. When I see a spade I call it a spade.Gwendolen. [Satirically.] I am glad to say that I have never seen a spade. It is obvious that our social spheres have been widely different.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “We have really everything in common with America nowadays, except, of course, language.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “High hopes were once formed of democracy; but democracy means simply the bludgeoning of the people by the people for the people.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is always painful to part from people whom one has known for a brief space of time. The absence of old friends one can endure with equanimity, But even a momentary separation from anyone to whom one has just been introduced is almost unbearable.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You are a sceptic." "Never! Scepticism is the beginning of faith." "What are you?" "To define is to limit.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Because sometimes you have to do something bad to do something good.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I am jealous of everything whose beauty does not die.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist, that is all”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Good heavens! how marriage ruins a man! It's as demoralizing as cigarettes, and far more expensive.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “If I could get back my youth, I'd do anything in the world except get up early, take exercise or be respectable.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I have spent most of the day putting in a comma and the rest of the day taking it out.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Thirty-five is a very attractive age. London society is full of women of the very highest birth who have, of their own free choice, remained thirty-five for years.”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Romantic literature is in effect imaginative lying.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Time is a waste of money.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I am not at all cynical, I have merely got experience, which, however, is very much the same thing. ”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Anybody can have common sense, povided that they have no imagination”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “If a man treats life artistically, his brain is his heart”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is the confession, not the priest, that gives us absolution.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Only dull people are brilliant at breakfast”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Every single human being should be the fulfilment of a prophecy: for every human being should be the realisation of some ideal, either in the mind of God or in the mind of man.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “you will always love, and you will always be loved”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “But what world says that [I'm wicked]? It can only be the next world. This world and I are on excellent terms.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Young men want to be faithful, and are not. Old men want to be faithless, and cannot.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I hope to-morrow will be a fine day, Lane.It never is, sir.Lane, you're a perfect pessimist.I do my best to give satisfaction, sir.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “All sins, except a sin against itself, Love should forgive. All lives, save loveless lives, true Love should pardon.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Behind every exquisite thing that existed, there was something tragic. World's had to be in travail, that the meanest flower might blow...”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a question of nerves, and fibres, and slowly built-up cells in which thought hides itself and passion has its dreams.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “sorrow...is a wound that bleeds when any hand but that oflove touches it”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The aim of Love is to love: no more, and no less.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “My dear Algy, you talk exactly as if you were a dentist. It is very vulgar to talk like a dentist when one isn't a dentist. It produces false impression”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “When a golden girl can winPrayer from out the lips of sin,When the barren almond bears,And a little child gives away its tears,Then shall all the house be stillAnd peace come to Canterville.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I represent to you all the sins you have never had the courage to commit.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Men know life too early. Women know life too late. That is the difference between men and women.”
author: Oscar wilde

quote: “It is always a silly thing to give advice, but to give good advice is absolutely fatal.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is better to have a permanent income than to be fascinating.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I am a born antinomian. I am one of those who are made for exceptions, not for laws. But while I see that there is nothing wrong in what one does, I see that there is something wrong in what one becomes.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Nothing annoys people so much as not receiving invitations.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Nature....she will hang the night stars so that I may walk abroad in the darkness without stumbling, and send word the wind over my footprints so that none may track me to my hurt: she will cleanse me in great waters, and with bitter herbs make me whole.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You love the beauty that you can see and touch and handle, the beauty that you can destroy, and do destroy, but of the unseen beauty of life, of the unseen beauty of a higher life, you know nothing. You lost life's secret.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “We should treat all the trivial things of life seriously, and all the serious things of life with sincere and studied triviality.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Believe me, no civilized man ever regrets a pleasure, and no uncivilized man ever knows what a pleasure is.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Know thyself' was written over the portal of the antique world. Over the portal of the new world, 'Be thyself' shall be written.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “All great ideas are dangerous.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The studio was filled with the rich odour of roses, and when the light summer wind stirred amidst the trees of the garden, there came through the open door the heavy scent of the lilac, or the more delicate perfume of the pink-flowering thorn.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Youth is the only thing worth having. When I find that I am growing old, I shall kill myself.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “How clever are you, my dear! You never mean a single word you say!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The only excuse for making a useless thing is that one admires it intensely. All art is quite useless.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “If they know nothing of victory, they are at least spared the knowledge of defeat.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The curves of your lips rewrite history.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I always like to know everything about my new friends, and nothing about my old ones.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “He covered page after page with wild words of sorrow and wilder words of pain. There is a luxury in self-reproach. When we blame ourselves, we feel that no one else has a right to blame us. It is the confession, not the priest, that gives us absolution.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One's past is what one is. It is the only way by which people should be judged.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Well, in the first place girls never marry the men they flirt with. Girls don't think it right.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Nowadays we are all of us so hard up that the only pleasant things to pay are compliments. They’re the only things we can pay.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “MRS ALLONBY I adore them. The clever people never listen, and the stupid people never talk.HESTER I think the stupid people talk a great deal.MRS ALLONBY Ah, I never listen!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Ultimately the bond of all companionship, whether in marriage or in friendship, is conversation.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One is tempted to define man as a rational animal who always loses his temper when he is called upon to act in accordance with the dictates of reason.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “A man cannot be too careful in the choice of his enemies.”
author: oscar wilde

quote: “Our ambition should be to rule ourselves, the true kingdom for each one of us; and true progress is to know more, and be more, and to do more.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You are Beautiful when you are happy”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The one duty we owe to history is to rewrite it.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “With the abolition of private property, then, we shall have true, beautiful, healthy Individualism. Nobody will waste his life in accumulating things, and the symbols of things. One will live. To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist, that is all.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Even things that are true can be proved.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “What art seeks to disturb is monotony of type, slavery of custom, tyranny of habit, and the reduction of man to the level of a machine.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “My great mistake, the fault for which I can’t forgive myself, is that one day I ceased my obstinate pursuit of my own individuality. ”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There were moments when he looked on evil simply as a mode through which he could realize his conception of the beautiful.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Don't squander the gold of your days, listening to the tedious, trying to improve the hopeless failure, or giving away your life to the ignorant, the common, and the vulgar”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It would be unfair to expect other people to be as remarkable as oneself”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “People are very fond of giving away what they need most themselves.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I have given away my whole soul to some one who treats it as if it were a flower to put in his coat, a bit of decoration to charm his vanity, an ornament for a summer's day.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Each of us has heaven and hell in him, Basil, cried Dorian with a wild gesture of despair.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Oh, I don’t care about Jack. I don’t care for anybody in the whole world but you. I love you, Cecily. You will marry me, won’t you?You silly boy! Of course. Why, we have been engaged for the last three months.For the last three months?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is very wrong to kill any one[.]""Oh, I hate the cheap severity of abstract ethics!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “When I was young I thought money was the most important thing in life, now that I'm old - I know it is!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Each time that one loves is the only time one has ever loved. Difference of object does not alter singleness of passion. It merely intensifies it. We can have but one great experience at best, and the secret of life is to reproduce that experience as often as possible.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I am completely penniless, and absolutely homeless. Yet there are worse things in the world than that.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The burden of this world is too great for one man to bear, and the world’s sorrow too heavy for one heart to suffer.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “LORD ILLINGWORTH What do you think she'd do if I kissed her?MRS ALLONBY Either marry you, or strike you across the face with her glove. What would you do if she struck you across the face with her glove?LORD ILLINGWORTH Fall in love with her, probably.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “She lacks the indefinable charm of weakness.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Things are because we see them, and what we see, and how we see it, depends on the Arts that influenced us. To look at a thing is very different from seeing a thing. One does not see anything until one sees its beauty. Then, and then only, does it comes into existence.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “He is fond of being misunderstood. It gives him a post of vantage.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Pleasures may turn a heart to stone, riches may make it callous, but sorrows cannot break it. Hearts live by being wounded.”
author: Oscar Wilde Bestseller Novel

quote: “It was always once springtime in my heart.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Each man lived his own life and paid his own price for living it. The only pity was one had to pay so often for a single fault. One had to pay over and over again, indeed. In her dealings with man, Destiny never closed her accounts.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is not the perfect, but the imperfect, who have need of love. It is when we are wounded by our own hands that love should come to cure us.Else what use is love at all?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The unspeakable in pursuit of the uneatable!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I don't like compliments and I don't see why a man should think he is pleasing a woman enormously when he says to her a whole heap of things that he doesn't mean.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The terror of society, which is the basis of morals, the terror of God, which is the secret of religion-these are the two things that govern us.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Even you are not rich enough, Sir Robert, to buy back your past. No man is”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Selfishness is not living as one wishes to live. It is asking other people to live as one wishes to live.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Religions die when they are proved to be true. Science is the record of dead religions.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Philanthropic people lose all sense of humanity. It is their distinguishing characteristic.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I believe I am to have enough to live on for about eighteen months at anyrate, so that if I may not write beautiful books, I may at least read beautifulbooks; and what joy can be greater?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Neither at things, nor at people should one look. Only in mirrors should one look, for mirrors do but show us masks.”
author: Oscar wilde

quote: “It’s absurd to divide people into good and bad. People are either charming or tedious.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There is a fatality about good resolutions – that they are always made too late”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To do nothing at all is the most difficult thing in the world, the most difficult and the most intellectual.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It was the passions about whose origin we deceived ourselves that tyrannized most strongly over us.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Muffins should always be eaten quite calmly, as it is the only way to eat them!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There is no Mystery so great as Misery.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There is a luxury in self-reproach. When we blame ourselves we feel that no one else has a right to blame us.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “but the bravest man among us is afraid of himself”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Everyone quoted it, it was full of so many words that they could not understand.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I have a business appointment that I am anxious... to miss.”

quote: “What the artist isalways looking for is the mode of existence in which soul and body areone and indivisible: in which the outward is expressive of the inward: inwhich form reveals.”

quote: “Ridicule is the tribute paid to the genius by the mediocrities”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I must decline your invitation owing to a subsequent engagement.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I knew that I had come face to face with some one whose mere personality was so fascinating that, if I allowed it to do so, it would absorb my whole nature, my whole soul, my very art itself.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It was you I thought of all the time, I gave to them the love you did not need: lavished on them a love that was not theirs.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “If after I am free a friend of mine gave a feast, and did not invite me to it, I should not mind a bit. I can be perfectly happy by myself. With freedom, flowers, books, and the moon, who could not be perfectly happy?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I hate people who talk about themselves, as you do, when one wants to talk about oneself, as I do. ”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One must be serious about something, if one wants to have any amusement in life.”
author: Oscar Wilde John Cooper

quote: “I really don't see what is so romantic about proposing. One may be accepted - one usually is, I believe - and then the excitement is ended. The very essence of romance is uncertainty.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The very essence of romance is uncertainty. If ever I get married, I'll certainly try to forget the fact.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “He hadn’t a single redeeming vice.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “In the old days men had the rack. Now they have the Press.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You became to me the visible incarnation of that unseen ideal whose memory haunts us artists like an exquisite dream.”

quote: “I was wrong. God's law is only Love.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I have got to make everything that has happened to me good for me”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Experience is simply the name we give our mistakes.”

quote: “I think life too complex a thing to be settled by these hard and fast rules.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The living always think that gold can make them happy”

quote: “In your soul are infinitely precious things that cannot be taken from you”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The supreme vice is shallowness.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “My dear Arthur, I never talk scandal. I only talk gossip.What is the difference between scandal and gossip?Oh! Gossip is charming! History is merely gossip. But scandal is gossip made tedious by morality.”

quote: “The truth is rarely pure and never simple. Modern life would be very tedious if it were either, and modern literature a complete impossibility!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You have never been poor, and never known what ambition is.”

quote: “A man who moralizes is a hypocrite, and a woman who does so is invariably plain.”

quote: “For he who lives more lives than oneMore deaths than one must die.”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “She wore far too much rouge last night and not quite enough clothes. That is always a sign of despair in a woman.”

quote: “It is only the intellectually lost who ever argue.”

quote: “To win back my youth, there is nothing I wouldn't do - except take exercise, get up early, or be a useful member of the community.”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is the uncertainty that charms one. A mist makes things wonderful.”

quote: “Youth is the only thing worth having.”

quote: “Then I am sorry I did not stay away longer I like being missed.”

quote: “There were opium-dens, where one could buy oblivion, dens of horror where the memory of old sins could be destroyed by the madness of sins that were new.”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I don't know that women are always rewarded for being charming. I think they are usually punished for it!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It's most dangerous nowadays for a husband to pay any attention to his wife in public. It always makes people think that he beats her when they are alone. The world has grown so suspicious of anything that looks like a happy married life.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “We can forgive a man for making a useful thing as long as he does not admire it”

quote: “Pleasure is Nature's test, her sign of approval.”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Christ did not die to save people, but to teach people how to save each other. This is, I have no doubt, a grave heresy, but it is also a fact.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Suffering is one very long moment. We cannot divide it by seasons. We can only record its moods, and chronicle their return.”

quote: “The only thing that one really knows about human nature is that it changes. Change is the one quality we can predicate of it. The systems that fail are those that rely on the permanency of human nature, and not on its growth and development.”

quote: “I like to do all the talking myself.  It saves time, and prevents arguments.” “But”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The fact is, that I told him a story with a moral.” “Ah! that is always a very dangerous thing to do,”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Inteligence lives longer than beauty.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The fact is that the public have an insatiable curiosity to know everything, except what is worth knowing.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The girl never really lived, and so she has never really died.”

quote: “God and other artists are always a little obscure.....”

quote: “The birds that were singing in the dew-drenched garden seemed to be telling the flowers about her.”

quote: “God made the world just as much for me as for any one else.”

quote: “Everyone is worthy of love, except him who thinks that he is. Love is a sacrament that should be taken kneeling.”

quote: “Those whom the gods love grow young.”

quote: “The fatal errors of life are not due to man's being unreasonable: an unreasonable moment may be one's finest moment. They are due to man's being logical.”

quote: “The note of the perfect personality is not rebellion, but peace.”

quote: “He is some brainless, beautiful creature, who should always be here in winter when we have no flowers to look at, and always here in the summer when we want something to chill our intelligence.”

quote: “Oh, I love London Society! It has immensely improved. It is entirely composed now of beautiful idiots and brilliant lunatics. Just what Society should be.”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Like two doomed ships that pass in stormWe had crossed each other's way:But we made no sign, we said no word,We had no word to say;”
author: Oscar Wilde

author: Oscar Wilde

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “And when wind and winter hardenAll the loveless land,It will whisper of the garden,You will understand.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I was dominated, soul, brain, and power by you. You became to me the visible incarnation of that unseen ideal whose memory haunts us artists like an exquisite dream.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To become a work of art is the object of living.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “And the child smiled on the Giant, and said to him, 'You let me play once in your garden, to-day you shall come with me to my garden, which is Paradise.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The truth is rarely pure and never simple.  Modern life would be very tedious if it were either, and modern literature a complete impossibility!”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “My friend is not allowed to go out today. I sit by his side and read him passages from his own life. They fill him with surprise. Everyone should keep someone else's diary; I sometimes suspect you of keeping mine.”

quote: “One should never do anything that one cannot talk about after dinner.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You know we poor artists have to show ourselves in society from time to time, just to remind the public that we are not savages.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “But don't you think one can be happy when on is married?Perfectly happy. But the happiness of a married man, my dear Gerald, depends on the people he has not married.But if one is in love?One should always be in love. That is the reason one should never marry.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Sometimes, the unnecessary is necessary.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “JACKYour duty as a gentleman calls you back. ALGERNONMy duty as a gentleman has never interfered with my pleasures in the smallest degree.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It can never be necessary to do what is not honourable.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “A method of procuring sensations? Do you think then, that a man who has once committed a murder could possibly do the same crime again? Don't tell me that." says Dorian."Oh! anything becomes a pleasure if one does it too often," says Lord Henry”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “If one tells the truth, one is sure, sooner or later, to be found out.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I worshipped you too much. I am punished for it. You worshipped yourself too much. We are both punished.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Life has always poppies in her hands.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I like hearing myself talk. It is one of my greatest pleasures. I often have long conversations all by myself, and I am so clever that I sometimes don't understand a single word of what I am saying.”

quote: “Punctuality is but the thief of time”

quote: “MRS ALLONBY Have you tried a good reputation?LORD ILLINGWORTH It is one of the many annoyances to which I have never been subjected.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “the costume of the nineteenth century is detestable. It is so sombre, so depressing. Sin is the only real colour-element left in modern life.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “He is all my art to me now.”

quote: “Civilization is not by means an easy thing to attain to. There are only two ways by which man can reach it. One is by being cultured, the other by being corrupt.”

quote: “Your vanity is ridiculous, your conduct an outrage, and your presence in my garden utterly absurd”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Faithfulness is to the emotional life what consistency is to the life of the intellect - simply a confession of failures.”

quote: “She lacks the indefinable charm of weakness. It is the feet of clay that make the gold of the image precious.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Indifference is the revenge the world takes on mediocrities.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Unless one is wealthy there is no use in being a charming fellow. Romance is the priviledge of the rich, not the profession of the unemployed. The poor shall be practical and prosaic. It is better to have a permanent income than to be fascinating.”

quote: “Men marry because they are tired; women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.”

quote: “Some cause happiness wherever they go; others, whenever they go.”

quote: “Every little action of the common day makes or unmakes character.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I have been right, Basil, haven’t I, to take my love out of poetry, and to find my wife in Shakespeare’s plays? Lips that Shakespeare taught to speak have whispered their secret in my ear. I have had the arms of Rosalind around me, and kissed Juliet on the mouth.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Perhaps in nearly every joy, as certainly in every pleasure, cruelty has its place.”
author: Oscar Wilde

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “love is not fashionable any more, the poets have killed it. ”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I love talking about nothing, father. It is the only thing I know anything about.”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “anything becomes a pleasure if one does it too often,”

quote: “beautiful sins, like beautiful things, are the privilege of the rich”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “In America, the young are always ready to give to those who are older than themselves the full benefit of their inexperience.”

quote: “To reveal art and conceal the artist is art's aim.”

quote: “Books are well written, or badly written. That is all.”

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The Number our envious Persons, confirmation our capability.”

quote: “The brotherhood of man is not a mere poet’s dream: it is a most depressing and humiliating reality.”

quote: “Things are because we see them, and what we see, and how we see it, depends on the Arts that have influenced us.”

quote: “I threw the pearl of my soul into a cup of wine. I went down the primrose path to the sound of flutes. I lived on honeycomb.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “In fact, now you mention the subject, I have been very bad in my own small way.I don't think you should be so proud of that, though I am sure it must have been very pleasant.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You see, it is a very dangerous thing to listen. If one listens one may be convinced; and a man who allows himself to be convinced by an argument is a thoroughly unreasonable person.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The mutilation of the savage has its tragic survival in the self-denial that mars our lives.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is better to repent a sin than regret the loss of a pleasure.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “some kill their love when they are young,and some when they are old;some strangle with the hands of lust,some with the hands of gold:THE KINDEST USE A KNIFE, becauseTHE DEAD SO SOON GROW COLD.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One should never take sides in anything, Mr. Kelvil. Taking sides is the beginning of sincerity, and earnestness follows shortly afterwards, and the human being becomes a bore.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Art has no influence upon action. It annihilates the desire to act. It is superbly sterile. The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To recommend thrift to the poor is both grotesque and insulting. It is like advising a man who is starving to eat less.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Even now I cannot help feeling that it is a mistake to think that the passion one feels in creation is ever really shown in the work one creates.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “We can forgive a man for making a useful thing as long as he does not admire it. The only excuse for making a useless thing is that one admires it intensely.All art is quite useless.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I forgot that little action of the common day makes or unmakes character, and therefore what one has done in the secret chamber one has someday to cry aloud on the housetops.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Love - well, not love at first sight, but love at the end of the season, which is so much more satisfactory.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “between the famous and the infamous there is but one step, if as muchas one”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To be in Society is merely a bore. But to be out of it simply a tragedy. Society is a necessary thing.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Silently we went round and round,And through each hollow mindThe memory of dreadful thingsRushed like a dreadful wind,And horror stalked before each man,And terror crept behind.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It's beauty that captures your attention; personality that captures your heart..”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I made your sorrow mine also, that you might have help in bearing it.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Perhaps one never seems so much at one's ease as when one has to play a part.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “They have been eating muffins. That looks like repentance”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I never saw sad men who lookedWith such a wistful eye Upon that little tent of blue We prisoners called the sky, And at every happy cloud that passed In such strange freedom by.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “For life is terribly deficient in form. Its catastrophes happen in the wrong way and to the wrong people. There is a grotesque horror about its comedies, and its tragedies seem to culminate in farce.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is always painful to part from people whom one has known for a very brief space of time. The absence of old friends one can endure with equanimity. But even a momentary separation from anyone to whom one has just been introduced is almost unbearable.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is perfectly monstrous," he said, at last, "the way people go about nowadays saying things against one behind one's back that are absolutely and entirely true.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I suppose one must be serious sometimes.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I remember your saying once that there is a fatality about good resolutions—that they are always made too late. Mine certainly were.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There is an unknown land full of strange flowers and subtle perfumes, a land of which it is joy of all joys to dream, a land where all things are perfect and poisonous.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The life that was to make his soul would mar his body.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I like hearing myself talk.  It is one of my greatest pleasures.  I often have long conversations all by myself, and I am so clever that sometimes I don’t understand a single word of what I am saying.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Well, I can't eat muffins in an agitated manner. The butter would probably get on my cuffs. One should always eat muffins quite calmly. It is the only way to eat them.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The proper basis for marriage is mutual misunderstanding. The happiness of a married man depends on the people he has not married. One should always be in love - that's the reason one should never marry.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The moment you think you understand a great work of art, it's dead for you.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Look at the moon! How strange the moon seems! She is like a woman rising from a tomb. She is like a dead woman. You would fancy she was looking for dead things.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I will love you always, because you will always be worthy of love.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Tea is the only simple pleasure left to us.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “How does one cure the soul? Through the senses”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “We in the House of Lords are never in touch with public opinion. That makes us a civilised body.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One should never give a woman anything she can't wear in the evening.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I give the truths of tomorrow.""I prefer the mistakes of today," she answered.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I would sooner lose my best friend than my worst enemy. To have friends, you know, one need only be good-natured; but when a man has no enemy left there must be something mean about him.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Everybody one meets is a paradox nowadays. It is a great bore. It makes society so obvious.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Did you hear what I was playing, Lane?I didn't think it polite to listen, sir.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “But Venice, like Oxford, had kept the background for romance, and, to the true romantic, background was everything, or almost everything.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “MRS ALLONBY You have your looking-glassLORD ILLINGWORTH It is unkind. I merely shows me my wrinkles.MRS ALLONBY Mine is better behaved. It never tells me the truth.LORD ILLINGWORTH Then it is in love with you.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Bad art is a great deal worse than no art at all.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “M. Zola sits down to give us a picture of the Second Empire. Who cares for the Second Empire now? It is out of date. Life goes faster than Realism, but Romanticism is always in front of Life.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One cannot always keep an adder in one's breast to feed one, nor rise up every night to sow thorns in the garden of one's soul.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You are remarkably modern, Mabel. A little too modern, perhaps. Nothing is so dangerous as being too modern. One is apt to grow old-fashioned quite suddenly.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “while to propose to be a better man is a piece of unscientific cant, to have become a deeper man is the privilege of those who have suffered. And such I think I have become.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Of course, I should have got rid of you. I should have shaken you out of my life as a man shakes from his raiment a thing that has stung him.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Can they feel, I wonder, those white silent people we call the dead?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “American girls are as clever at concealing their parents as English women are at concealing their past.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “In love, one always begins in deceiving oneself, and one always ends in deceiving others.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I never quarrel with actions. My one quarrel is with words”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “JACKYou're quite perfect, Miss Fairfax.GWENDOLENOh! I hope I am not that. It would leave no room for developments, and I intend to develop in many directions.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I have pleasures, and passions, but the joy of life is gone. I am going under: the morgue yawns for me. I go and look at my zinc-bed there. After all, I had a wonderful life, which is, I fear, over.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To call an artist morbid because he deals with morbidity as his subject-matter is as silly as if one called Shakespeare mad because he wrote ‘King Lear.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “We all look at Nature too much, and live with her too little.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “A well-tied tie is the first serious step in life.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “He grew more and more enamoured of his own beauty, more and more interested in the corruption of his own soul.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is only intellectually lost who ever argue.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Skepticism is the beginning of faith.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “by nature and by choice, i am extremely indolent.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “In the strangely simple economy of the world people only get what they give, and to those who have not enough imagination to penetrate the mere outward of things and feel pity, what pity can be given save that of scorn?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Once in New York, you are sure to be a great success. I know lots of people there who would give a hundred thousand dollars to have a grandfather, and much more than that to have a family ghost.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To make a good salad is to be a brilliant diplomat - the problem is entirely the same in both cases. To know how much oil to mix in with one's vinegar.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “we can’t stand other people having the same faults as ourselves”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The best amongst the poor are never grateful. They are ungrateful, discontented, disobedient, and rebellious. They are quite right to be so.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “For these treasures, and everything that he collected in his lovely house, were to be to him means of forgetfulness, modes by which he could escape, for a season, from the fear that seemed to him at times to be almost too great to be borne.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Prism! Where is that baby?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To get back one's youth, one has merely to repeat one's follies.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The real drawback to marriage is that it makes one unselfish. And unselfish people are colourless. They lack individuality.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The unread is always better than the unreadable.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Morality is simply the attitude we adopt towards people whom we personally dislike. You dislike me. I am quite aware of that. And I have always detested you. (Mrs. Cheveley)”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Morality does not help me. I am a born antinomian. I am one of those who are made for exceptions, not for laws. But while I see that there is nothing wrong in what one does, I see that there is something wrong in what one becomes. It is well to have learned that.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The post on her left was occupied by Mr. Erskine of Treadley, an old gentleman of considerable charm and culture, who had fallen, however, into bad habits of silence, having, as he explained once to Lady Agatha, said everything that he had to say before he was thirty.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “They say that love hath a bitter taste.... But what matter? What matter? I have kissed thy mouth.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Of course, married life is merely a habit, a bad habit. But then one regrets the loss even of one's worst habits. Perhaps one regrets them the most. They are such an essential part of one's personality.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Ah! ah! wherefore didst thou not look at me? If thou hadst looked at me thou hadst loved me. Well I know that thou wouldst have loved me, and the mystery of Love is greater than the mystery of Death.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Love is a wonderful thing. It is more precious than emeralds and dearer than fine opals. pearls and pomegranates cannot buy it, nor is it set forth in the market-place. It may not be purchased of the merchants, nor can it be weighted out in the balance for gold.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “When he takes the knife to the canvass the servants find him lying dead with a knife through is heart and "withered, wrinkled, and loathsome of visage." and the portrait "in all the wonders of his exquisite youth and beauty." p 349”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Women try their luck; men risk theirs.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Jack: “Gwendolen, it is a terrible thing for a man to find out suddenly that all his life he has been speaking nothing but the truth. Can you forgive me?”Gwendolen: “I can. For I feel that you are sure to change.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “But I loved Narcissus because as he lay on my banks and looked down at me, in the mirror of his eyes I saw ever my own beauty mirrored.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “And when you are away, Gerald...with...her - oh, think of me sometimes. Don't forget me.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The fact is, that the public have an insatiable curiosity to know everything, except what is worth knowing. ”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Women have no appreciation of good looks—at least, good women have not.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “From your silken hair to your delicate feet you are perfection to me. Pleasure hides love from us, but pain reveals it in its essence.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “When he [Christ] says 'Forgive your enemies', it is not for the sake of the enemy but for one's own sake that he says so, and because Love is more beautiful than Hate.”

quote: “There is no such thing as good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral- immoral from a scientific point of view.”

quote: “Most people are other people. Their thoughts are someone else’s opinions, their lives a mimicry, their passions a quotation.”

quote: “Algy, you always adopt a strictly immoral attitude towards life. You are not quite old enough to do that.”

quote: “I see that any materialism in life coarsens the soul, and that the hunger of the body and the appetites of the flesh desecrate always, and often destroy.”

quote: “It is only about things that do not interest one, that one can give a really unbiassed opinion; and this is no doubt the reason why an unbiased opinion is always valueless.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “We live, I regret to say, in an age of surfaces”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “And once, or twice, to throw the dice is a gentlemanly game, But he does not win who plays with Sin in the secret house of shame”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You used to stir my imagination. Now you don't even stir my curiosity.”

quote: “Why didn't you tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Illness of any kind is hardly a thing to be encouraged in others. Health is the primary duty of life.”

quote: “Death is the only thing that ever terrifies me. I hate it.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Come, I tell you. You have chattered enough about corruption. Now you shall look on it face to face!”

quote: “And they are unjust to us often, for when they find life bitter they blame us for it, and when they find it sweet we do not taste its sweetness with them.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To be good is to be in harmony with ones self. Discord is to be forces to be in harmony with others.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “For the future let those who come to play with me have no hearts”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “out of sorrow have the worlds been built, and at the birth of a child or a star, there is pain”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The harmony of soul and body - how much that is! We in our madness have separated the two, and have invented a realism that is vulgar, and ideality that is void.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I am sorry my life is so marred and maimed by extravagance. But I cannot live otherwise. I, at any rate, pay the penalty of suffering.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I have invented an invaluable permanent invalid called Bunbury, in order that I may be able to go down into the country whenever I choose.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “My father told me to go to bed an hour ago. I don't see why I shouldn't give you the same advice. I always pass on good advice. It is the only thing to do with it. It is never of ant use to oneself.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “something was dead in each of us,and what was dead was hope.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “A woman will flirt with anybody in the world as long as other people are looking on.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Lord AUGUSTUS:(looking around) Time to educate yourself, I suppose.DUMBY: No, time to forget all I have learned. That is much more important.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Well, I know, of course, how important it is not to keep a business engagement, if one wants to retain any sense of the beauty of life.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Let those who have not walked as we have done,In the red fire of passion, those whose livesAre dull and colourless, in a word let those,If any such there be, who have not loved,Cast stones against you”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It would be more impressive if it flowed the other way (Commenting on Niagara Falls)”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Relations are simply a tedious pack of people, who haven’t got the remotest knowledge of how to live, nor the smallest instinct about when to die.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The ages live in history through their anachronisms.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It takes a thoroughly good woman to do a thoroughly stupid thing.”

quote: “Indeed, in many respects, she was quite English, and was an excellent example of the fact that we have really everything in common with America nowadays, except, of course, language.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “LADY BRACKNELLI had some crumpets with Lady Harbury, who seems to me to be living entirely for pleasure now.ALGERNONI hear her hair has turned quite gold from grief.”
author: Oscar Wilde

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Define us as a sex.LORD ILLINGWORTH Sphinxes without secrets.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “As for a spoiled life, no life is spoiled but one whose growth is arrested. If you want to mar a nature, you have merely to reform it.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To tell people what to read is, as a rule, either useless or harmful; for the appreciation of literature is a question of temperament not of teaching; to Parnassus there is no primer and nothing that one can learn is ever worth learning.”

quote: “You will always be loved, and you will always be in love with love.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Oh! talk to every woman as if you loved her and to every man as if he bored you, and at the end of your first season you will have the reputation of possessing the most perfect social tact.”

quote: “On an occasion of this kind it becomes more than a moral duty to speak one's mind. It becomes a pleasure.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “we shall all suffer for what the gods have given us, suffer terribly.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is immoral to use private property in order to alleviate the horrible evils that result from the institution of private property. ”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The only difference between the saint and the sinner is that every saint has a past, and every sinner has a future.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One should never trust a woman who tells one her real age. A woman who would tell one that, would tell one anything.”

quote: “I have also learnt sympathy with suffering. To me, suffering seems now a sacramental thing, that makes those whom it touches holy.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “LORD ILLINGWORTH. The only difference between the saint and the sinner is that every saint has a past, and every sinner has a future. LADY”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There was something tragic in a friendship so colored by romance.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I don’t at all like knowing what people say of me behind my back. It makes me far too conceited.”
author: Oscar Wilde "An Ideal Husband"

quote: “For the recognition of private property has really harmed Individualism, and obscured it, by confusing a man with what he possesses.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Never trust a woman who wears mauve.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It would kill the past, and when that was dead, he would be free.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “it is a marvel that those red-roseleaf lips of yours should be made no less for the madness of music and song than for the madness of kissing.”

quote: “It is personalities, not principles, that move the age”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The commonest thing is delightful if one only hides it.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Mr. Henry James writes fiction as if it were a painful duty.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Being adored is a nuisance. Women treat us just as humanity treats its gods. They worship us, and are always bothering us to do something for them.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To be good, according to the vulgar standard of goodness, is obviously quite easy. It merely requires a certain amount of sordid terror, a certain lack of imaginative thought, and a certain low passion for middle-class respectability.”
author: Oscar WIlde

quote: “And each man kills the thing he loves.”

quote: “The more he knew, the more he desired to know. He had mad hungers that grew more ravenous as he fed them.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “you seem to be displaying signs of triviality.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The pen is mightier than the paving-stone”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Keep love in your heart. A life without it is like a sunless garden when the flowers are dead.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “They did not understand a single word of what he was saying, but that made no matter, for they put their heads on one side, and looked wise, which is quite as good as understanding a thing, and very much easier.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “for there is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I don't like novels that end happily. They depress me so much.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Champing his gilded oats, the Hippogriff will stand in our stalls, and over our heads will float the Blue Bird singing of beautiful and impossible things, of things that are lovely and that never happen, of things that are not and that should be.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You came to me to learn the Pleasure of Life and the Pleasure of Art. Perhaps I am chosen to teach you something much more wonderful, the meaning of Sorrow and its beauty.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Things last either too long or not long enough.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The drawback of stealing a thing, is that one never knows how wonderful the thing that one steals is.”

quote: “As for a spoiled life, no life is spoiled but one whose growth is arrested.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The pure and simple truth is, the truth is never pure and simple.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There is something terribly morbid in the modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathise with the colour, the beauty, the joy of life. The less said about life's sores the better.”
author: Oscar Wilde

author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “There is always something ridiculous about the emotions of people whom one has ceased to love. Sibyl Vane seemed to him to be absurdly melodramatic. Her tears and sobs annoyed him.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “What was youth at best? A green, an unripe time, a time of shallow moods, and sickly thoughts.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “In America the president reigns for 4 years, and journalism governs for ever and ever.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “To him, man was a being with myriad lives and myriad sensations, a complex multiform creature that bore within itself strange legacies of thought and passion, and whose very flesh was tainted with the monstrous maladies of the dead.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Your mysterious young friend, whose name you have never told me, but whose picture really fascinates me, never thinks.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I remembered what you had said to me on that wonderful evening we first dined together, about the search for beauty being the real secret of life…”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You let me play once in your garden, to-day you shall come with me to my garden, which is Paradise.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “No artist desires to prove anything. Even things that are can be proved. No artist has ethical sympathies. An ethical sympathy in an artist is an unpardonable mannerism of style. No artist is ever morbid. The artist can express everything.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One should never make one's debut with a scandal. One should reserve that to give an interest to one's old age.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “By the way, Dorian, he (Lord Henry) said, after a pause, what does it profit a man if he gain the whole world and lose - how does the quotation run? - his own soul? ”

quote: “Pinkerton's Champion Stain Remover and Paragon Detergent”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The passion for property is in it. There are many things that we would throw away if we were not afraid others might pick them up.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “That certainly seems a satisfactory explanation, does it not?– Yes dear, if you can believe him.– I don't. But that does not affect the wonderful beauty of his answer.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Yes, we are overcharged for everything nowadays. I should fancy that the real tragedy of the poor is that they can afford nothing but self-denial. Beautiful sins, like beautiful things, are the privilege of the rich.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The only artists I have ever known, who are personally delightful, are bad artists. Good artists exist simply in what they make, and consequently are perfect uninteresting in what they are.”

quote: “Life is short, art is infinite.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “A rose shook in her blood and shadowed her cheeks. Quick breath parted the petals of her lips. They trembled. Some southern wind of passion swept over her and stirred the dainty folds of her dress. "I love him", she said simply.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The world loves the Saint, and Christ loves the sinner.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I am always astonishing myself. It is the only thing that makes life worth living.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The man who sees both sides of a question is a man who sees absolutely nothing.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “That's an awful thing,a womans memory”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “No object is so beautiful that, under certain conditions, it will not look ugly”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “It is simply expression, as Henry says, that gives reality to things.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The man who says his wife can't take a joke, forgets she took him.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One can realise a thing in a single moment, but one loses it in the long hours that follow with leaden feet. ”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Yet the roses are not less lovely for all that.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Of course married life is merely a habit, a bad habit. But then one regrets the loss even of one's worse habits.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “You have not realized how I have developed. I was a schoolboy when you knew me. I am a man now. I have new passions new thoughts new ideas. I am different but you must not like me less. I am changed but you must always be my friend.”

quote: “She was usually in love with somebody, and, as her passion was never returned, she had kept all her illusions.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “At every single moment of one's life one is what one is going to be no less than what one has been.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “I can sympathise with everything, except suffering", cried Lord Harry, Shrugging his shoulders. "I cannot sympathise with that. It is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid in the modern sympathy with pain.”

quote: “It is not he who is revealed by the painter; it is rather the painter, who on the coloured canvas, reveals himself.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “One should not look at anything. Neither at things, nor at people should one look. Only in mirrors is it well to look, for mirrors do but show us masks.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “Faithfulness! I must analyze it some day. The passion for property is in it. There are many things that we would throw away if we were not afraid that others might pick them up.”
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: “The arts that have escaped [uniformity] best are the arts in which the public take no interest. Poetry is an instance of what I mean. We have been able to have fine poetry in England because the public do not read it, and consequently do not influence it.”

quote: “Happiness is the feeling that power increases - that resistance is being overcome.”
