quote: “Humanity is the quality which stops one being arrogant towards one's fellows, or being acrimonious.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “It is a small part of life we really live.’ Indeed, all the rest is not life but merely time.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Prove - and an easy task it is - that so-called pleasures, when they go beyond a certain limit, are but punishments...”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “So the man who restrains himself within the bounds set by nature will not notice poverty; the man who exceeds these bounds will be pursued by poverty however rich he”
author: Seneca

quote: “Let us take pleasure in what we have received and make no comparison; no man will ever be happy if tortured by the greater happiness of another.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It should be our care not so much to live a long life as a satisfactory one.”
author: Seneca

quote: “There is nothing in the world so much admired as a man who knows how to bear unhappiness with courage."— Seneca”
author: Seneca

quote: “If you look on wealth as a thing to be valued you’ll always fancy yourself to be short of the things you need to the extent to which you lag behind what others have.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The man who spends his time choosing one resort after another in a hunt for peace and quiet will in every place he visits find something to prevent him from relaxing.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “Sorrowers tend to avoid what they are most fond of and try to give vent to their grief.”
author: Seneca

quote: “An unpopular rule is never long maintained.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “We are, therefore, seeking how the mind can follow a smooth and steady course, well disposed to itself, happily regarding its own condition and with no interruption to this pleasure, but remaining in a state of peace with no ups and downs: that will be tranquillity.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It’s not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.” -Lucius Annaeus Seneca”
author: Seneca

quote: “The mind when distracted absorbs nothing deeply.”
author: Seneca the Younger

quote: “Oh, what darkness does great prosperity cast over our minds!”
author: Seneca

quote: “How silly then to imagine that the human mind, which is formed of the same elements as divine beings, objects to movement and change of abode, while the divine nature finds delight and even self-preservation in continual and very rapid change.”
author: Seneca

quote: “I can show you a philtre, compounded without drugs, herbs, or any witch's incantation: 'If you want to be loved, love.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Let us prepare our minds as if we’d come to the very end of life. Let us postpone nothing. Let us balance life’s books each day. … The one who puts the finishing touches on their life each day is never short of time.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Love of bustle is not industry.”
author: Seneca the Younger

quote: “So it is inevitable that life will be not just very short but very miserable for those who acquire by great toil what they must keep by greater toil.”
author: Seneca

quote: “To be everywhere; is to be nowhere”
author: Seneca the Elder

quote: “There is but one chain holding us in fetters, and that is our love of life.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “There is no great genius without a tincture of madness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Wherever there is a human being, there exists the opportunity for an act of kindness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Where you arrive does not matter so much as what sort of person you are when you arrive there.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The highest good is a mind that scorns the happenings of chance, and rejoices only in virtue.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “It takes all of our life to learn how to live, and – something that may surprise you more – it takes just as long to learn how to die.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Life, if you know how to use it, is long; but…many, following no fixed aim, shifting and… dissatisfied, are plunged by their fickleness into plans that are ever new; some have no fixed principle by which to direct their course.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “there are a few men whom slavery holds fast, but there are many more who hold fast to slavery.”
author: Seneca

quote: “But it is one thing to remember, another to know. Remembering is merely safeguarding something entrusted to the memory; knowing, however, means making everything your own; it means not depending upon the copy and not all the time glancing back at the master.”
author: Seneca

quote: “In the ashes all men are levelled. We're born unequal, we die equal.”
author: Seneca

quote: “When Zeno received news of a shipwreck and heard that all his luggage had been sunk he said, "Fortune bids me to be a less encumbered philosopher.”
author: Seneca

quote: “You squander time as if you drew from a full and abundant supply, though all the while that day which you bestow on some person or thing is perhaps your last.”
author: Seneca

quote: “And so when you see a man often wearing the robe of office, when you see one whose name is famous in the Forum, do not envy him; those things are bought at the price of life. They will waste all their years, in order that they may have one year reckoned by their name.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “by overloading the body with food you strangle the soul and render it less active.”
author: Seneca

quote: “To live under constraint is a misfortune, but there is no constraint to live under constraint.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Believe me if you consult philosophy she will persuade you not to lit so long at your counting desk”
author: Seneca

quote: “what is freedom, you ask?  It means not being a slave to any circumstance, to any constraint, to any chance; it”
author: Seneca

quote: “And when the soul has yielded to pleasure, its functions and actions grow weak, and any undertaking comes from a nerveless and unsteady source.”
author: Seneca

quote: “One can expect an agreement between philosophers sooner than between clocks.”
author: Seneca

quote: “He will live ill who does not know how to die well”
author: Seneca

quote: “There is nothing the busy man is less busied with than living: there is nothing that is harder to learn.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Similarly, too rich a soil makes the grain fall flat, branches break down under too heavy a load, excessive productiveness does not bring fruit to ripeness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Possession of a friend should be with the spirit: the spirit's never absent: it sees daily whoever it likes.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The greatest loss of time is delay and expectation, which depend upon the future. We let go the present, which we have in our power, and look forward to that which depends upon chance, and so relinquish a certainty for an uncertainty.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “From this state also will he flee. If I should attempt to enumerate them one by one, I should not find a single one which could tolerate the wise man or which the wise man could tolerate.”
author: Seneca

quote: “True happiness is...to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Life’s like a play. It’s not the length but the excellence of the acting that matters.”
author: Seneca the Younger

quote: “No man has escaped paying the penalty for being born.”
author: Seneca

quote: “...nothing happens to the wise man against his expectation.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The day which we fear is out last is buth the birthday of eternity”
author: Seneca

quote: “Those who forget the past, ignore the present, and fear for the future have a life that is very brief and filled with anxiety: when they come to face death, the wretches understand too late that for such a long time they have busied themselves in doing nothing.”
author: Seneca

quote: “What then is good? The knowledge of things. What is evil? The lack of knowledge of things.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No good thing renders its possessor happy, unless his mind is reconciled to the possibility of loss.”
author: Seneca

quote: “pleasure, unless it has been kept within bounds, tends to rush headlong into the abyss of sorrow.”
author: Seneca

quote: “I am loath to call clemency what was, rather, the exhaustion of cruelty.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “A good man will not waste himself upon mean and discreditable work or be busy merely for the sake of being busy.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We are weak, watery beings standing in the midst of unrealities; therefore let us turn our minds to the things that are everlasting.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Everyone hurries his life on and suffers from a yearning for the future and a weariness of the present. But he who bestows all of his time on his own needs, who plans out every day as if it were his last, neither longs for nor fears the morrow.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It is the sign of a weak mind to be unable to bear wealth.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Theseus: What is the crime for which you must pay by death?Phaedra: My life.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Human greatness is not discovered until it is tested; we must be hardened against fortune by fortune itself”
author: Seneca

quote: “Anyone who likes may make things easier for himself by viewing them with equanimity.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Associate with those who will make a better man of you. Welcome those whom yourself can improve. Men learn while they teach.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Suspice, etiam si decidunt, magna conantes " "Admire those who attempt great things, even though they fail""Admira, incluso si caen, a quienes emprenden grandes iniciativas”
author: Seneca

quote: “Any man,’ he says, ‘who does not think that what he has is more than ample, is an unhappy man, even if he is the master of the whole world.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Truth often harms the one who digs it up.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Why not stop trying to prevent posterity being silent about you? You were born to die, and a silent funeral is less bothersome.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The important thing about a problem is not its solution, but the strength we gain in finding the solution.”
author: Seneca

quote: “what's the use of overcoming opponent after opponent in the wrestling or boxing rings if you can be overcome by your temper?”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “In times of happiness, no point in shaking things up.But in a time of crisis, the safest thing is change.”
author: Seneca

quote: “When things are at their worst, there are no tears.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The wise man, he said, lacked nothing but needed a great number of things, whereas 'the fool, on the other hand, needs nothing (for he does not know how to use anything) but lack everything.”
author: Seneca

quote: “we are mistaken when we look forward to death; the major portion of death has already passed, Whatever years be behind us are in death's hands.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Be silent as to services you have rendered, but speak of favours you have received.”
author: Seneca the Younger

quote: “Philosophy is good advice; and no one can give advice at the top of his lungs.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “Pain is slight if opinion has added nothing to it; ... in thinking it slight, you will make it slight. Everything depends on opinion. It is according to opinion that we suffer. A man is as wretched as he has convinced himself that he is.”
author: Seneca

quote: “A great mind becomes a great fortune.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “It is in times of security that the spirit should be preparing itself for difficult times; while fortune is bestowing favors on it is then is the time for it to be strengthened against her rebuffs.”
author: Seneca

quote: “the fates lead those who will those who won't they drag.”
author: Seneca

quote: “…because it is natural to touch more often the parts that hurt.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We are indeed apt to ascribe certain faults to the place or to the time; but those faults will follow us, no matter how we change our place.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “You must linger among a limited number of master thinkers, and digest their works, if you would derive ideas which shall win firm hold in your mind. ”
author: Seneca

quote: “All fools suffer the burden of dissatisfaction with themselves.”
author: Seneca the Elder

quote: “While we are postponing, life speeds by.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “to make Pythocles rich, do not add to his store of money, but subtract from his desires.”
author: Seneca

quote: “All things were ready for us at our birth; it is we that have made everything difficult for ourselves, through our disdain for what is easy.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The best remedy for anger is delay”
author: Seneca

quote: “the man who spends all his time on his own needs, who organizes every day as though it were his last, neither longs for nor fears the next day.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For how little have we lost, when the two finest things of all will accompany us wherever we go, universal nature and our individual virtue.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The wise man will live as long as he ought, not as long as he can”
author: Seneca

quote: “Finally, it is generally agreed that no activity can be successfully pursued by an individual who is preoccupied”
author: Seneca

quote: “Ignorance is no cure for suffering.”
author: Seneca

quote: “the preoccupied become aware of it only when it is over.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The man who has anticipated the coming of troubles takes away their power when they arrive.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Spurn everything that is added by way of decoration and display by unneccesary labour. Relect that nothing merits admiration except the spirit, the impressiveness of which prevents it from being impressed by anything.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “Our universe is a sorry little affair unless it has in it something for every age to investigate.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Mankind is perpetually the victim of a pointless and futile martydom, fretting life away in fruitless worries though failure to realise what limit is set to acquisition and to the growth of genuine pleasure”
author: Seneca

quote: “The happy man is satisfied with his present situation, no matter what it is, and eyes his fortune with contentment; the happy man is the one who permits reason to evaluate every condition of his existence.”
author: Seneca

quote: “He who needs riches least, enjoys riches most."[8]”
author: Seneca

quote: “Everyone hustles his life along, and is troubled by a longing for the future and weariness of the present.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Above all, my dear Lucilius, make this your business: learn how to feel joy.”
author: Seneca Lucius Annaeus

quote: “The surest way for those who want to rule is praising moderation, talking of peace and quiet.”
author: Seneca

quote: “There is never a time when new distraction will not show up; we sow them, so several will grow from the same seed.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Nothing satisfies greed, but even a little satisfies nature.”
author: Seneca

quote: “if we do not want to be overwhelmed and struck numb by rare events as if they were unprecedented ones; fortune needs envisaging in a thoroughly comprehensive way.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Life’s finest day for wretched mortals here Is always first to flee.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For all other things, which arouse our desires, depress the soul and weaken it, and when we think that they are uplifting the soul, they are merely puffing it up and cheating it with much emptiness. Therefore, that alone is good which will make the soul better.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Everyone goes out of life just as if he had but lately entered.”
author: Seneca

quote: “You act like mortals in all that you fear, and like immortals in all that you desire.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Men love their country, not because it is great, but because it is their own.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Reasons for anxiety will never be lacking, whether born of prosperity or of wretchedness; life pushes on in a succession of engrossments. We shall always pray for leisure, but never enjoy it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Night brings our troubles to the light rather than banishes them.”
author: Seneca

quote: “If you gain from a crime, you did it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Stop preventing philosophers from possessing money; no one has condemned wisdom to poverty. I will despise whatever lies in the domain of Fortune, but if a choice is offered, I will choose the better half.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Restless people often pretend to be calm.”
author: Seneca

quote: “There is an old adage about gladiators, - that they plan their fight in the ring.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Think for a long time whether or not you should admit a given person to your friendship. But when you have decided to do so, welcome him heart and soul, and speak as unreservedly with him as you would with yourself”
author: Seneca

quote: “I think the pinnacle of misfortune is to be forced by chance to want things one should loathe.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Living is the least important activity of the preoccupied man;”
author: Seneca

quote: “And there’s no state of slavery more disgraceful than one which is self-imposed.”
author: Seneca

quote: “What difference does it make whether they are slaves of free men, freeborn or freedmen, owing their freedom to the laws or to a gift made in the presence of friends? Wherever there is a human being, there exists the opportunity for an act of kindness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “since the mind when distracted absorbs nothing deeply, but rejects everything which is, so to speak, crammed into it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “In guarding their fortune men are often closefisted, yet, when it comes to the matter of wasting time, in the case of the one thing in which it is right to be miserly, they show themselves most prodigal.”
author: Seneca

quote: “prosperity does not elevate the sage and adversity does not depress him. For he has always made the effort to rely as much as possible on himself and to derive all delight from himself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Therefore, my dear Lucilius, begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life. He who has thus prepared himself, he whose daily life has been a rounded whole, is easy in his mind;”
author: Seneca

quote: “No one can live happily who has regard for himself alone and transforms everything into a question of his own utility”
author: Seneca

quote: “How much better to follow a straight course and attain a goal where the words "pleasant" and "honourable" have the same meaning!”
author: Seneca

quote: “The wise man will not upset the customs of the people, nor will he invite the attention of the populace by any novel ways of living.”
author: Seneca

quote: “it makes no difference how important the provocation may be, but into what kind of soul it penetrates. Similarly with fire; it does not matter how great is the flame, but what it falls upon.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The most important contribution to peace of mind is never to do wrong. Those who lack self-control lead disturbed and tumultuous lives; their crimes are balanced by their fears, and they are never at ease.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Add to this that he who laughs at the human race deserves better of it than he who mourns for it, for the former leaves it some good hopes of improvement, while the latter stupidly weeps over what he has given up all hopes of mending.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Time heals what reason cannot.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Our soul is sometimes a king, sometimes a tyrant. An uncontrolled, over-indulged soul is turned from a king to the most-feared tyrant.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Count your years, and you will be ashamed to desire and pursue the same things you desired in your boyhood days. ”
author: Seneca

quote: “No man is despised by another unless he is first despised by himself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No man has been shattered by the blows of Fortune unless he was first deceived by her favours.”
author: Seneca

quote: “You want to live - but do you know how to live? You are scared of dying - and, tell me, is the kind of life you lead really any different from being dead?”
author: Seneca

quote: “For to be afflicted with endless sorrow at the loss of someone very dear is foolish self-indulgence, and to feel none is inhuman callousness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No one dies except on his own day. You are throwing away none of your own time; for what you leave behind does not belong to you.”
author: Seneca

quote: “I wish Lucilius you had been so happy as to have taken this resolution long ago I wish we had not deferred to think of an happy life till now we are come within light of death But let us delay no longer”
author: Seneca

quote: “Socrates made the same remark to one who complained; he said: "Why do you wonder that globe-trotting does not help you, seeing that you always take yourself with you? The reason which set you wandering is ever at your heels.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We Stoics are not subjects of a despot: each of us lays claim to his own freedom.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Now all men suffer from ignorance of the truth; deceived by common report, they make for these ends as if they were good, and then, after having won their wish, and suffered much, they find them evil, or empty, or less important than they had expected.”
author: Seneca

quote: “One cannot sincerely weep over getting what one wanted.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Retire into yourself as much as you can. Associate with people who are likely to improve you. Welcome those whom you are capable of improving.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No man is so faint-hearted that he would rather hang in suspense for ever than drop once for all.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Virtue is according to nature; vice is opposed to it and hostile.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity!”
author: Seneca

quote: “we should often withdraw into ourselves; for mixing with persons of dissimilar natures throws into disorder our settled composure and wakens our passions anew, exacerbating whatever is weak in the mind and not properly healed.”
author: Seneca

quote: “we are not given a short life but we make it short, and we are not ill-supplied but wasteful of it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Do you ask what is the foundation of a sound mind? It is, not to find joy in useless things. ”
author: Seneca

quote: “You ask what progress I have made? I have begun to be a friend to myself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Reflect that nothing merits admiration except thespirit, the impressiveness of which prevents it from being impressed by anything.”
author: Seneca

quote: “But consider whether you may not get more help from the customary method[1] than from that which is now commonly called a "breviary," though in the good old days, when real Latin was spoken, it was called a "summary."[2]”
author: Seneca

quote: “No delicate breeze brings comfort with icy breath of windto the hearts which pant on the flames.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The past is ours, and there is nothing more secure for us than that which has been. We are ungrateful for past gains, because we hope for the future, as if the future – if so be that any future is ours – will not be quickly blended with the past.”
author: Seneca

quote: “What is death? Either a transition or an end. I am not afraid of coming to an end, this being the same as never having begun, nor of transition, for I shall never be in confinement quite so cramped anywhere else as I am here.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “What's the good of dragging up sufferings which are over, of being unhappy now just because you were then?”
author: Seneca

quote: “we deceive ourselves in thinking that death only follows life whereas it both goes before and will follow after it for where is the difference in not beginning or ceasing to exist the effect of both is not to be”
author: Seneca

quote: “For we are mistaken when we look forward to death; the major portion of death has already passed. Whatever years be behind us are in death's hands.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Anger will abate and become more controlled when it knows it must come before a judge each day.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For if we could be satisfied with anything, we should have been satisfied long ago.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Wealth is the slave of the wise man and master of the fool.”
author: Seneca

quote: “That which takes effect by chance is not an art.”
author: Seneca

quote: “To be everywhere, is to be no where at all”
author: Seneca the Elder

quote: “Not all men are wounded in the same place; and so you ought to know what part of you is weak, so you can give it the most protection.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Every pleasure is most valued when it is coming to an end.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We do not need many words, but, rather, effective words.”
author: Seneca

quote: “What really ruins our characters is the fact that none of us looks back over his life. We think about what we are going to do, and only rarely of that, and fail to think about what we have done, yet any plans for the future are dependent on the past.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The liberal arts do not conduct the soul all the way to virtue, but merely set it going in that direction.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Let all your efforts be directed to something, let it keep that end in view. It's not activity that disturbs people, but false conceptions of things that drive them mad.”
author: Seneca

quote: “In every good person, there lives a god. Which god? We cannot be sure - but it is a god.”
author: Seneca

quote: “This evil of taking our cue from others has become so deeply ingrained that even that most basic feeling, grief, degenerates into imitation.”
author: seneca

quote: “You will notice that the most powerful and highly stationed men let drop remarks in which they pray for leisure, praise it, and rate it higher than all their blessings.”
author: Seneca

quote: “How much better it is that you defeat anger than that it defeats itself!”
author: Seneca

quote: “Nero: "Am I forbidden to do what all may do?"Seneca: "From high rank high example is expected.”
author: Seneca the Younger

quote: “No past life has been lived to lend us glory, and that which has existed before us is not ours.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “Look for the best and prepare for the worst.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Be aware, then, that every human condition is subject to change, and that whatever mishap can befall any man can also happen to you.”
author: Seneca

quote: “what is sweeter than to be so valued by one's wife that one becomes more valuable to oneself for this reason? Hence my dear Paulina is able to make me responsible, not only for her fears, but also for my own.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The day has already begun to lessen. It has shrunk considerably, but yet will still allow a goodly space of time if one rises, so to speak, with the day itself. We are more industrious, and we are better men if we anticipate the day and welcome the dawn;”
author: Seneca

quote: “To have may be taken from us, to have had, never. A man is thankless in the highest degree if, after losing something, he feels no obligation for having received it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The road is long if one proceeds by way of precepts but short and effectual if by way of personal example.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “You can put up with a change of place if only the place is changed.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For we are not summoned according to the paristi register And besides there is no man so old as to make it sinful to expect another day. Now every day is another step in life.”
author: seneca

quote: “If an evil has been pondered beforehand, the blow is gentle when it comes.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Treat your inferiors in the way in which you would like to be treated by your own superiors. And whenever it strikes you how much power you have over your slave, let it also strike you that your own master has just as much power over you.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Who scorns his own life is lord of yours.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Peace you can claim for yourself without being disliked by anyone, without any sense of loss, and without any pangs of spirit.”
author: Seneca

quote: “[On Time] Men trifle with the most precious thing in the world; but they are blind to it because it is an incorporeal thing, because it does not come beneath the sight of the eyes, and for this reason it is counted a very cheap thing—nay, of almost no value at all.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Furthermore, if you will pay close heed to the problem, you will find that the largest portion of our life passes while we are doing ill, a goodly share while we are doing nothing, and the whole while we are doing that which is not to the purpose.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The greatest wealth is a poverty of desires”
author: Seneca

quote: “The busy man is busy with everything except living; there is nothing that is more difficult to learn how to do right.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The fool's life is empty of gratitude and full of fears; its course lies wholly toward the future.”
author: Seneca

quote: “But every great and overpowering grief must take away the capacity to choose words, since it often stifles the voice itself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The body’s needs are few: it wants to be free from cold, to banish hunger and thirst with nourishment; if we long for anything more we are exerting ourselves to serve our vices, not our needs.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For what can be above the man who is above fortune?”
author: Seneca

quote: “When one is busy and absorbed in one's work, the very absorption affords great delight; but when one has withdrawn one's hand from the completed masterpiece, the pleasure is not so keen.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Of this one thing make sure against your dying day—let your faults die before you die”
author: Seneca

quote: “When Zeno received news of a shipwreck and heard that all his luggage had been sunk he said, 'Fortune bids me to be a less encumbered philosopher.”
author: Seneca

quote: “And what is more wretched than a man who forgets his benefits and clings to his injuries?”
author: Seneca

quote: “Undisturbed by fears and unspoiled by pleasures, we shall be afraid neither of death nor the gods.”
author: Seneca

quote: “So you must not think a man has lived long because he has white hair and wrinkles: he has not lived long, just existed long.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The acquisition of riches has been for many men, not an end, but a change, of troubles.”
author: Seneca

quote: “this will not be a gentle prescription for healing, but cautery and the knife. What shall I achieve? That a soul which has conquered so many miseries will be ashamed to worry about one more wound in a body which already has so many scars.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Iniquum est collapsis manum non porrigere: commune hoc ius generis humani est"(It is wrong not to stretch out your hand to the fallen: that is a common law of the human race)”
author: Seneca the Elder

quote: “None of these will force you to die, but all will teach you how to die. None of them will exhaust your years, but each will contribute his years to yours.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We often are angry," says our adversary, "not with men who have hurt us, but with men who are going to hurt us: so you may be sure that anger is not born of injury.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Nature does not reveal her mysteries once and for all.”
author: Seneca

quote: “To be everywhere; is to be nowhere.”
author: Seneca the Elder

quote: “We all rush through life torn between a desire for the future and a weariness of the present. But he who devotes his time to his own needs, who plans out every day as if it were his last, neither longs for nor fears for tomorrow. How”
author: Seneca

quote: “All those who engage you in their business disengage you from yourself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Could anything be more stupid than to praise a person for something that is not his? Or more crazy than admiring things which in a single moment can be transferred to another?”
author: Seneca

quote: “For what good does it do us to guide a horse and control his speed with the curb, and then find that our own passions, utterly uncurbed, bolt with us? Or to beat many opponents in wrestling or boxing, and then to find that we ourselves are beaten by anger?”
author: Seneca

quote: “No good thing is pleasant to possess, without friends to share it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Dum inter homines sumus, colamus humanitatem""As long as we are among humans, let us be humane”
author: Seneca

quote: “After friendship is formed you must trust, but before that you must judge.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Silently time sneaks up on you, each hour gone is followed by a worse one.”
author: Seneca Lucius Annaeus

quote: “But life is very short and anxious for those who forget the past, neglect the present, and fear the future. When they come to the end of it, the poor wretches realize too late that for all this time they have been preoccupied in doing nothing.”
author: Seneca

quote: “no man can live a happy life, or even a supportable life, without the study of wisdom; you know also that a happy life is reached when our wisdom is brought to completion, but that life is at least endurable even when our wisdom is only begun.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We shall consider later whether these evils derive their power from their own strength, or from our own weakness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Life is divided into three periods, past, present and future. Of these, the present is short, the future is doubtful, the past is certain.”
author: Seneca

quote: “But the man who is not puffed up in good times does not collapse either when they change.”
author: Seneca

quote: “I have never wished to cater to the crowd; for what I know, they do not approve, and what they approve, I do not know.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Men do not let anyone seize their estates, and if there is the slightest dispute about their boundaries they rush to stones and arms; but they allow others to encroach on their lives – why, they themselves even invite in those who will take over their lives.”
author: Seneca

quote: “But he must have richly dyed purple clothes, woven with gold thread and decorated with multicoloured patterns: it is his fault, not nature’s, if he feels poor.”
author: Seneca

quote: “How long will this last?’ This feeling has caused kings to bewail their power, and they were not so much delighted by the greatness of their fortune as terrified by the thought of its inevitable end.”
author: Seneca

quote: “If you shape your life according to nature, you will never be poor; if according to people's opinions, you will never be rich.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The greatest obstacle to living is expectancy, which hangs upon tomorrow and loses today.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Hence the dictum of the greatest of doctors:† ‘Life is short, art is long.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Every pleasure is most valued when it is coming to an end?”
author: Seneca

quote: “Let tears flow of their own accord: their flowing is not inconsistent with inward peace and harmony.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Whatever years be behind us are in death's hands.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Unless we are complete ingrates, the lives of all those men that preceded us should be seen as sacred. Their collective existence paved the way for our own time on Earth. Because”
author: Seneca

quote: “Fortuna est quae fit cum praeparatio in occasionem incidit. "Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity”
author: Seneca

quote: “Life is long enough, and it has been given in sufficiently generous measure to allow the accomplishment of the very greatest things if the whole of it is well invested.”
author: Lucius Seneca

quote: “Therefore, nothing ought to be unexpected by us. Our minds should be sent forward in advance to meet all problems, and we should consider, not what is wont to happen, but what can happen.”
author: Seneca

quote: “we are all bound by this oath: "To bear the ills of mortal life, and to submit with a good grace to what we cannot avoid.”
author: Seneca

quote: “A grey-haired wrinkled man has not necessarily lived long. More accurately, he has existed long.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We live in the middle of things which have all been destined to die. Mortal have you been born, to mortals you have given birth. Reckon on everything, expect everything.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We are born under circumstances that would be favorable if we did not abandon them. It was nature's intention that there should be no need of great equipment for a good life: every individual can make himself happy.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Despise everything that useless toil creates as an ornament and an object of beauty. And reflect that nothing except the soul is worthy of wonder; for to the soul, if it be great, naught is great."[4]”
author: Seneca

quote: “One of the causes of the troubles that beset us is the way our lives are guided by the example of others; instead of being set to rights by reason we’re seduced by convention.”
author: Seneca

quote: “He robs present ills of their power who has perceived their coming beforehand.”
author: Seneca

quote: “You can tell the character of every man when you see how he receives praise.”   Difficult”
author: Seneca

quote: “There are more things likely to frighten us than there are to crush us; we suffer more often in imagination than in reality.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It is clear to you, I know, Lucilius, that no one can lead a happy life, or even one that is bearable, without the pursuit of wisdom, and that the perfection of wisdom is what makes the happy life, although even the beginnings of wisdom make life bearable.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Unbroken prosperity cannot bear a single blow; but he who has waged an unceasing strife with his misfortunes has gained a thicker skin by his sufferings, yields to no disaster, and even though he fall yet fights on his knee.”
author: Seneca

quote: “it is only in the ideal or perfect state that the virtues of the good citizen and the good man are identical.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We live among wicked man through our own wickedness. One thing alone can bring us peace, an agreement to treat one another with kindness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No one willingly reverts to the past unless all his actions have passed his own censorship, which is never deceived.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Do you ask what is the proper limit to wealth? It is, first, to have what is necessary, and, second, to have what is enough.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It does not make any difference what a man say; what matters is how he feels, and not how he feels on one particular day but how he feels at all times.”
author: Seneca

quote: “...all life is a servitude. So you have to get used to your circumstances, complain about them as little as possible, and grasp whatever advantage they have to offer: no condition is so bitter that a stable mind cannot find some consolation in it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Who can doubt, my dear Lucilius, that life is the gift of the immortal gods, but that living well1 is the gift of philosophy?”
author: Seneca

quote: “You must reflect that fettered prisoners only at first feel the weight of the shackles on their legs: in time, when they have decided not to struggle against but to bear them, they learn from necessity to endure with fortitude, and from habit to endure with ease.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Any man, who does not think that what he has is more than ample, is an unhappy man, even if he is the master of the whole world.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Why then do you occupy me with the words rather than with the works of wisdom? Make me braver, make me calmer, make me the equal of Fortune, make me her superior. And I can be her superior, if I apply to this end everything that I learn. Farewell.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The belly will not listen to advice; it makes demands, it importunes. And yet it is not a troublesome creditor; you can send it away at small cost, provided only that you give it what you owe, not merely all you are able to”
author: Seneca

quote: “You have buried someone you loved. Now look for someone to love. It is better to make good the loss of a friend than to cry over him.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It is wrong to live under constraint; but no man is constrained to live under constraint.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Of all men only those who find time for philosophy are at leisure, only they are truly alive; for it is not only their own lifetime they guard well; they add every age to their own; all the years that have passed before them they requisition for their store.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Kings hate to hear the things they order spoken.”
author: Seneca

quote: “that deed and word should be in accord, that a man should be equal to himself under all conditions, and always the same.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No one becomes a laughingstock who laughs at himself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Pure love, careless of all other things, kindles the soul with desire for the beautiful object, not without the hope of a return of the affection.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For some persons the remedy should be merely prescribed; in the case of others, it should be forced down their throats. ”
author: Seneca

quote: “O, what blindness does great prosperity cast upon our minds!”
author: Seneca

quote: “Harmony makes small things grow; lack of harmony makes great things decay.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The best compromise between love and good sense is both to feel longing and to conquer it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “I find in the writings of our Hecato that the limiting of desires helps also to cure fears: "Cease to hope," he says, "and you will cease to fear.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Leisure without books is death, and burial of a man alive.” “Desultory”
author: Seneca

quote: “Kingdoms which act unjustly never last.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Some men have shrunk so far into dark corners that objects in bright daylight seem quite blurred to them.’ A”
author: Seneca

quote: “The first thing which philosophy undertakes to give is fellow-feeling with all men; in other words, sympathy and sociability.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Your ears are not simply for hearing tuneful sounds, mellow and sweetly played in harmony: you should also listen to laughter and weeping, to words flattering and acrimonious, to merriment and distress, to the language of men and to the roars and barking of animals.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Well then, shall we act like other men? Shall there be no distinction between ourselves and the world?" Yes, a very great one; let men find that we are unlike the common herd, if they look closely.”
author: Seneca

quote: “When we have done everything within our power, we shall possess a great deal: but we once possessed the world.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The many speak highly of you, but have you really any grounds for satisfaction with yourself if you are the kind of person the many understand? Your merits should not be outward facing.”
author: Seneca

quote: “...speak ill of yourself when by yourself; then you will become accustomed both to speak and to hear the truth.”
author: Seneca Lucius Annaeus

quote: “do the one thing that can render you really happy: cast aside and trample under foot all the things that glitter outwardly and are held out to you a by another or as obtainable from another;”
author: Seneca

quote: “For the soul is more powerful than any sort of Fortune; by its own agency it guides its affairs in either direction, and of its own power it can produce a happy life, or a wretched one.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It is shameful to hate a person who deserves your praises; but how much more shameful it is to hate someone for the very cause that makes him deserve your pity.”
author: Seneca

quote: “In the ashes all men are levelled.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Every new beginning comes from other beginning’s end.”
author: Seneca

quote: “for when one strays away from Nature one is compelled to crave, and fear, and be a slave to the things of chance.”
author: Seneca

quote: “There are more things that frighten us than injure us, and we suffer more in imagination than in reality.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Again, I may have less than I hoped for. But perhaps I was hoping for more than I should have.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Often it is better to hide an illness from the patient, because just the mere awareness of a disease can bring about death.”
author: Seneca

quote: “why should I demand of Fortune that she give rather than demand of myself that I should not crave? ”
author: Seneca

quote: “Again, do you call those men leisured who spend many hours at the barber’s simply to cut whatever grew overnight, to have a serious debate about every separate hair, to tidy up disarranged locks or to train thinning ones from the sides to lie over the forehead?”
author: Seneca

quote: “We must, therefore, take a less serious view of all things, tolerating them in a spirit of acceptance: It is more human to laugh at life than to weep tears over it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The one to whom nothing was refused, whose tears were always wiped away by an anxious mother, will not abide being offended.—De Ira 2.21.6”
author: Seneca

quote: “No condition is so distressing that a balanced mind cannot find some comfort in it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “A man should therefore grow accustomed to his state and complain about it as little as possible, seizing upon whatever good it may have.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It is the evil mind that gets first hold on all of us.  Learning virtue means unlearning vice.  We”
author: Seneca

quote: “For this is what makes us wicked: that no one of us looks back over his own life. Our thoughts are devoted only to what we are about to do. And yet our plans for the future always depend on the past.”
author: Seneca

quote: “How many have laid waste to your life when you weren’t aware of what you were losing, how much was wasted in pointless grief, foolish joy, greedy desire, and social amusements—how little of your own was left to you. You will realize you are dying before your time!”
author: Seneca

quote: “I shall expose and reopen all the wounds which have already healed.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Where, then, lies the mistake, since all men crave the happy life?  It is that they regard the means for producing happiness as happiness itself, and, while seeking happiness, they are really fleeing from it. For”
author: Seneca

quote: “Life is divided into three parts: what was, what is and what shall be. Of these three periods, the present is short, the future is doubtful and the past alone is certain. Only”
author: Seneca

quote: “We should conduct ourselves not as if we ought to live for the body, but as if we could not live without it. Our too great love for it makes us restless with fears, burdens us with cares, and exposes us to insults.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “I realize that these mental agitations of mine are not dangerous and won’t produce a storm. To express my complaint for you in a realistic metaphor, I am harried not by a tempest but by sea-sickness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Let my mind be fixed on itself, cultivate itself, have no external interest – nothing that seeks the approval of another; let it cherish the tranquillity that has no part in public or private concerns.”
author: Seneca

quote: “A person teaching and a person learning,' he said, 'should have the same end in view: the improvement of the latter.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “Although the sum and substance of the happy life is unalloyed freedom from care, and though the secret of such freedom is unshaken confidence... men gather together that which causes worry.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “all the works of mortal man have been doomed to mortality, and in the midst of things which have been destined to die, we live!”
author: Seneca

quote: “There is no easy way from the earth to the stars.”
author: Seneca the Younger

quote: “You have all the fears of mortals and all the desires of immortals”
author: Seneca

quote: “Everyone hustles his life along, and is troubled by a longing for the future and weariness of the present. But the man who spends all his time on his own needs, who organizes every day as though it were his last, neither longs for nor fears the next day.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It was nature’s intention that there should be no need of great equipment for a good life: every individual can make himself happy.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Epicurus: “If you live according to nature, you will never be poor; if you live according to opinion, you will never be rich.”
author: Seneca

quote: “There is no need to complain of particular grievances, for life in its entirety is lamentable.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Finally, it is generally agreed that no activity can be successfully pursued by an individual who is preoccupied - not rhetoric or liberal studies - since the mind when distracted absorbs nothing deeply, but rejects everything which is, so to speak, crammed into it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The greatest hindrance to living is expectancy, which depends upon the morrow and wastes to-day.”
author: Seneca

quote: “He suffers more than is necessary, who suffers before it is necessary;”
author: Seneca

quote: “Wherever there is a human being, there is an opportunity for crisis.” “We”
author: Seneca

quote: “the wise man is self-sufficient, that he can do without friends, not that he desires to do without them. When I say "can," I mean this: he endures the loss of a friend with equanimity.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Lay hold of to-day's task, and you will not need to depend so much upon tomorrow's.”
author: Seneca

quote: “takes the whole of life to learn how to live, and — what will perhaps make you wonder more — it takes the whole of life to learn how to die.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Only the wise man is content with what is his. All foolishness suffers the burden of dissatisfaction with itself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “YOU ask me to say what you should consider it particularly important to avoid. My answer is this: a mass crowd.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Do you call that man leisured who arranges with anxious precision his Corinthian bronzes, the cost of which is inflated by the mania of a few collectors, and spends most of the day on rusty bits of metal?”
author: Seneca

quote: “Would you rather be poor and sated, or rich and hungry? Prosperity is not only greedy, but it also lies exposed to the greed of others. And as long as nothing satisfies you, you yourself cannot satisfy others.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Poor woman, do you want to know where hatred ends? Look to love.”
author: Seneca

quote: “In sapientis quoque animo, etiam cum uulnus sanatum est, cicatrix manet." : "The wise man's mind will keep its scar long after the wound has healed”
author: Seneca

quote: “Let us postpone nothing. Let us balance life's account every day... One who daily puts the finishing touches to his life is never in want of time.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Everywhere means nowhere. When a person spends all his time in foreign travel, he ends by having many acquaintances, but no friends.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It is unbearable to be deprived of your country.' Come now, look at this mass of people whom the buildings of huge Rome can scarcely hold: most of that crowd are deprived of their country.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No one," he says, "leaves this world in a different manner from one who has just been born." That is not true; for we are worse when we die than when we were born; but it is our fault, and not that of Nature.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it. Life is long enough, and a sufficiently generous amount has been given to us for the highest achievements if it were all well invested.”
author: Seneca

quote: “You complain that there is an undersupply of books where you are. What matters is not how many you have but how good they are. Varied reading gives pleasure; selective reading does real good.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “Those who are busy with other things do not notice it until the end comes.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Men learn as they teach.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It is so, my dear Lucilius; there are a few men whom slavery holds fast, but there are many more who hold fast to slavery.”
author: Seneca

quote: “if you wish to make Pythocles an old man, filling his life to the full, do not add to his years, but subtract from his desires.”
author: Seneca

quote: “if you wish Pythocles to have pleasure for ever, do not add to his pleasures, but subtract from his desires";”
author: Seneca

quote: “Ubicumque ex aequo ad caelum erigitur acies, paribus intervallis omnia divina ab omnibus humanis distant - From whatever point on the earth's surface you look up to heaven the same distance lies between the realms of gods and men”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “Do you ask me what this real good is, and whence it derives? I will tell you: it comes from a good conscience, from honourable purposes, from right actions, from contempt of the gifts of chance, from an even and calm way of living which treads but one path.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Why do you wonder that globe-trotting does not help you, seeing that you always take yourself with you? The reason which set you wandering is ever at your heels.”

quote: “A trifling debt makes a man your debtor; a large one makes him an enemy.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Thus the time we are given is not brief, but we make it so. We do not lack time; on the contrary, there is so much of it that we waste an awful lot.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Nature’s wants are slight; the demands of opinion are boundless.”
author: Seneca

quote: “why should I demand of Fortune that she give rather than demand of myself that I should not crave? And why should I crave? Shall I heap up my winnings, and forget that man’s lot is unsubstantial? For what end should I toil?”
author: Seneca

quote: “If you are empty-handed, the highwayman passes you by: even along an infested road, the poor may travel in peace.”
author: Seneca

quote: “You must linger among a limited number of master thinkers, and digest their works, if you would derive ideas which shall win firm hold in your mind. Everywhere means nowhere.”
author: Seneca

quote: “That man is happiest, and is secure in his own possession of himself, who can await the morrow without apprehension. When a man has said: “I have lived!”, every morning he arises he receives a bonus.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Strangeness adds to the weight of calamities, and every mortal feels the greater pain as a result of that which also brings surprise.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The one who knows no hope knows no despair.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Those who forget the past, ignore the present, and fear for the future have a life that is very brief and filled with anxiety.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Poverty will keep for you your true and tried friends; you will be rid of the men who were not seeking you for yourself, but for something which you have.”
author: Seneca

quote: “If you would escape your troubles, you need not another place but another personality. Perhaps you have reached Athens, or perhaps Rhodes; choose any state you fancy, how does it matter what its character may be? You will be bringing to it your own.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Wisdom is the perfect good of the human mind; philosophy is the love of wisdom, and the endeavor to attain it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No man is born rich. Every man, when he first sees light, is commanded to be content with milk and rags. Such is our beginning, and yet kingdoms are all too small for us!”
author: Seneca

quote: “You must reflect carefully beforehand with whom you are to eat and drink, rather than what you are to eat and drink. For a dinner of meats without the company of a friend is like the life of a lion or a wolf.”
author: Seneca

quote: “To reduce your worry, you must assume that what you fear may happen is certainly going to happen.”
author: Seneca

quote: “All the greatest blessings are a source of anxiety, and at no time is fortune less wisely trusted than when it is best”
author: Seneca

quote: “We always feel anger longer than we feel hurt.”
author: Seneca

quote: “who as though inspired with divine utterance sings salutary verses: Life”
author: Seneca

quote: “We ought frequently to remind ourselves that we must love the things of this life as we would what is shortly to leave us, or indeed in the very act of leaving us.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “They are pleased to deceive themselves, as if they deceived Fate at the same time.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Nothing is burdensome if taken lightly.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Reflect on the things which goad man into destroying man: you will find that they are hope, envy, hatred, fear, and contempt.”
author: Seneca

quote: “And even though it is ordained to be, what does it avail to run out to meet your suffering? You will suffer soon enough, when it arrives; so look forward meanwhile to better things.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Why do you voluntarily deceive yourself and require to be told now for the first time what fate it is that you have long been labouring under? Take my word for it: since the day you were born you are being led thither.”
author: Seneca

quote: “we perish because we follow other men's examples: we should be cured of this if we were to disengage ourselves from the herd;”
author: Seneca

quote: “Live in this belief: “I am not born for any one corner of the universe; this whole world is my country.”
author: Seneca

quote: “A pleasure that is ephemeral brings no true satisfaction to any man. How miserable must be the lives of those folk who labor so hard for something that once gained they must work even harder to keep. They”
author: Seneca

quote: “If you want to determine the nature of anything, entrust it to time: when the sea is stormy, you can see nothing clearly”
author: Seneca

quote: “Everyone goes out of life just as if he had but lately entered it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “And I hold that no man has treated mankind worse than he who has studied philosophy as if it were some marketable trade, who lives in a different manner from that which he advises.”
author: Seneca

quote: “he has published the truth abroad that he is most happy who has no need of happiness, and that he is most powerful who has power over himself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The day will come when studies pursued over many centuries will reveal in all clarity things that are now hidden, and posterity will be astonished that we had failed to grasp these truths.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Again, when my mind is lifted up by the greatness of its thoughts, it becomes ambitious for words and longs to match its higher inspiration with its language, and so produces a style that conforms to the impressiveness of the subject matter.”
author: Seneca

quote: “There is therefore no advice—and of such advice no one can have too much—which I would rather give you than this: that you should measure all things by the demands of Nature; for these demands can be satisfied either without cost or else very cheaply.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “It takes the whole of life to learn how to live, and - what will perhaps make you wonder more - it takes the whole of life to learn how to die.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Devotion to what is right is simple, devotion to what is wrong is complex and admits of infinite variations.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The performer must always be stronger than his task: loads that are too heavy for the bearer are bound to overwhelm him.”
author: Seneca

quote: “You live as if you will live forever, no care for your mortality ever enters your head, you pay no mind to how much time has already gone by.”
author: Seneca

quote: “linger among a limited number of master thinkers, and digest their works,”
author: Seneca

quote: “You need never believe that a man can become happy through the unhappiness of another.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Disasters, therefore, and losses, and wrongs, have only the same power over virtue that a cloud has over the sun.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Plague on it! what madness this is, to punish one's self because one is unfortunate, and not to lessen, but to increase one's ills!”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “How closely flattery resembles friendship! It not only apes friendship, but outdoes it, passing it in the race; with wide-open and indulgent ears it is welcomed and sinks to the depths of the heart, and it is pleasing precisely wherein it does harm.”
author: Seneca

quote: “He who needs riches least, enjoys riches most.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Does it serve any useful purpose to know that Pompey was the first to exhibit the slaughter of eighteen elephants in the Circus, pitting criminals against them in a mimic battle?”
author: Seneca

quote: “Ask about those whose names are learned by heart, and you will see that they have these distinguishing marks: X cultivates Y and Y cultivates Z – no one bothers about himself.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The point is, not how long you live, but how nobly you live. And often this living nobly means that you cannot live long.”
author: Seneca

quote: “A hungry people neither listens to reason nor is mollified by fair treatment or swayed by any appeals.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For that is the people’s verdict, but wise men on the whole reject the people’s decrees.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Fortune recently took away her mother, but your love will mean that she will only grieve over her mother’s loss but not suffer for it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “No man is at the mercy of affairs. He gets entangled in them of his own accord, and then flatters himself that being busy is a proof of happiness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “It takes the whole of life to learn how to live, and — what will perhaps make you wonder more — it takes the whole of life to learn how to die.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Not single is the death which comes; the death Which takes us off is but the last of all.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For these two things are, as it were, at opposite poles—good Fortune and good sense; that is why we are wiser when in the midst of adversity. It is prosperity that takes away righteousness.”
author: Seneca

quote: “If none were happy, none would believe himself unfortunate, however great his troubles. Take away wealth, and gold, and thriving lands with droves of oxen at the plough - how then the spirits of the down-pressed poor would rise! What is misfortune but comparison?”
author: Seneca

quote: “Stolid pack-animals are much more fit for carrying loads than thoroughbred horses: who ever subdued their noble speed with a heavy burden?”
author: Seneca

quote: “Where, then, lies the mistake, since all men crave the happy life? It is that they regard the means for producing happiness as happiness itself, and, while seeking happiness, they are really fleeing from it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Honours, monuments, whatever the ambitious have ordered by decrees or raised in public buildings are soon destroyed: there is nothing that the passage of time does not demolish and remove.”
author: Seneca

quote: “But you never deign to look at yourself or listen to yourself. So you have no reason to claim credit from anyone for those attentions, since you showed them not because you wanted someone else’s company but because you could not bearyour own.”
author: Seneca

quote: “they are like prowling enemies who pounce on you when occasion offers, and allow you neither to be at the ready as in war nor at ease as in peace.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Most men ebb and flow in wretchedness between the fear of death and the hardships of life; they are unwilling to live, and yet they do not know how to die.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “It is one thing to understand the merits and the values of facts, another thing to know the precise moment for action, and still another to curb impulses and to proceed, instead of rushing, toward what is to be done.”
author: Seneca

quote: “But those who forget the past, neglect the present, and fear for the future have a life that is very brief and troubled; when they have reached the end of it, the poor wretches perceive too late that for such a long while they have been busied in doing nothing.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Read good books many times,rather than many books”
author: Seneca

quote: “Ask nature: she will tell you that she made both day and night.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Believe me, it takes a great man and one who has risen far above human weaknesses not to allow any of his time to be filched from him,”
author: Lucius Seneca

quote: “If you want to keep a secret, never share it.”
author: Seneca

quote: “A few is enough for me; so is one; and so is none.”
author: Seneca

quote: “there can be no place of exile within the world since nothing within the world is alien to men.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Wherever there is a human being, there is an opportunity for a kindness.” “A”
author: Seneca

quote: “Am I not to inquire into the identity of the artist of this universe?”
author: Seneca

quote: “Here is your noble spirit – the one which has put itself in the hands of fate; on the other side we have the puny degenerate spirit which struggles, and which sees nothing right in the way the universe is ordered, and would rather reform the gods than reform itself.”

quote: “If these wish to know how short their life is, let them reflect how small a part of it is their own.”
author: Seneca

quote: “For you have no reason to suppose that we come to grief more through the flattery of others than through our own.”
author: Seneca

quote: “We are waves of the same sea, leaves of the same tree, flowers from the same garden.”
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: “If you are wise, mingle these two elements: do not hope without despair, or despair without hope.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Do you ask what is the proper limit to wealth? It is, first, to have what is necessary, and, second, to have what is enough. Farewell.”
author: Seneca

quote: “det ille veniam facile, cui venia est opus - the one who needs pardon should readily grant it”
author: Seneca

quote: “Those who lack self-control lead disturbed and tumultuous lives; their crimes are balanced by their fears, and they are never at ease.”
author: Seneca

quote: “All that remains of our existence is not actually life but merely time.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Life is long and there is enough of it for satisfying personal accomplishments if we use our hours well.”

quote: “You are to concern yourself no more about what the world says of you, but what you say of yourselves.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The present alone can make no man wretched.”

quote: “But if you keep turning round and looking about, in order to see how much you may carry away with you, and how much money you may keep to equip yourself for the life of leisure, you will never find a way out.”

author: Seneca

quote: “Those who choose to have no real purpose in life are ever rootless and dissatisfied, tossed by their aimlessness into ever-changing situations.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Your wise man, who is also a craftsman, will reject or choose in each case as it suits the occasion; but he does not fear that which he rejects, nor does he admire that which he chooses, if only he has a stout and unconquerable soul.”

quote: “You fear everything as mortals but desire to have everything as gods.”
author: Seneca

quote: “everywhere the people are of mixed and imported stock. One group has followed another: one longed for what another scorned; one was driven out from where he had expelled others. So fate has decreed that nothing maintains the same condition forever.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Consider individuals, survey men in general; there is none whose life does not look forward to the morrow. 13. "What harm is there in this," you ask? Infinite harm; for such persons do not live, but are preparing to live.”

quote: “Philosophy did not find Plato already a nobleman ; it made him one.”
author: Seneca

quote: “What Chance has made yours is not really yours.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Not happy he who thinks himself not so.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Let no one rob me of a single day who is not going to make me an adequate return for such a loss.”

author: Seneca

author: Seneca

quote: “Take my word for it: since the day you were born you are being led thither.”
author: Seneca

quote: “to be everywhere is to be nowhere”

quote: “Nothing is so bitter that a calm mind cannot find comfort in it.”

quote: “So the wise man will never provoke the anger of those in power; nay, he will even turn his course, precisely as he would turn from a storm if he were steering a ship.”
author: Seneca

quote: “By the toil of others we are led into the presence of things which have been brought from darkness into light. We are excluded from no age, but we have access to them all;”

author: Seneca

quote: “That from which you are running, is within you.”

quote: “Why do you postpone yourself?”

quote: “For the wise man regards wealth as a slave, the fool as a master.”

quote: “For certain ailments must be treated while the patient is unaware of them:”

quote: “Men are not made restless by activity but driven to madness by false impressions of reality.”

quote: “It is precisely in times of immunity from care that the soul should toughen itself beforehand for occasions of greater stress, and it is while Fortune is kind that it should fortify itself against her violence.”

quote: “we suffer more often in imagination than in reality.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Every man, when he first sees light, is commanded to be content with milk and rags. Such is our beginning, and yet kingdoms are all too small for us!”

quote: “Men do not care how nobly they live, but only how long, although it is within the reach of every man to live nobly, but within no man's power to live long. Farewell.”

quote: “The best part of life are flitting by, the worse are to come.”

quote: “No man can have a peaceful life who thinks too much about lengthening it”
author: Seneca

quote: “Epicurus said: If you shape your life according to nature, you will never be poor, if according to people's opinions, you will never be rich”

author: Seneca

quote: “One who seeks friendship for favourable occassions strips it of all its nobility.”

quote: “it has been a stock criticism of Seneca right down the centuries – between his philosophical teachings and his practice.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Fruit tastes most delicious just when its season is ending.”

quote: “An ordinary act repeated consistently over time creates extraordinary results”
author: Seneca

quote: “What is the happy life? It is peace of mind, and lasting tranquillity. This will be yours if you possess greatness of soul; it will be yours if you possess the steadfastness that resolutely clings to a good judgment just reached.”

author: Seneca

quote: “What can reason do? Passion, passion rules.”
author: Seneca

quote: “(About Philosophy) Give your whole mind to her. Sit at her side and pay her constant court, and an enormous gap will widen between yourself and other men. You'll end up far in advance of all mankind, and not far behind the gods themselves.”
author: Seneca

quote: “Men trifle with the most precious thing in the world; but they are blind to it because it is an incorporeal thing, because it does not come beneath the sight of the eye, and for this reason it is counted a very cheap thing-nay, of almost no value at all.”
author: Seneca

quote: “You squander time as if you drew from a full and abundant supply, though all the while that day which you bestow on some person or thing is perhaps your last.  You have all the fears of mortals and all the desires of immortals.”
author: Seneca

quote: “The primary indication, to my thinking, of a well-ordered mind is a man's ability to remain in one place and linger in his own company”

quote: “Life without ideals is erratic:”
author: Seneca

quote: “No man was ever wise by chance.”

quote: “You ask what is the proper limit to a person’s wealth? First, having what is essential, and second, having what is enough.”

quote: “It is too easy to side with the majority.”

quote: “Therefore it is better to conquer our grief than to deceive it.”
